description: A quick, practical guide to Black ASL: A Separate Dialect.

buildup.text: Black deaf students attended segregated schools from the 1860s through the 1960s.

discovery.text: Isolated from white ASL, Black deaf communities developed their own vocabulary and signing style.

twist.text: Black ASL uses more two-handed signs, a larger signing space, and more facial expression.

climax.text: Linguists only began studying Black ASL seriously in the 2000s â€” decades after segregation ended.

punchline.text: Segregation divided even a language you can't hear into separate dialects.

quiz.question: How did Black ASL develop?
options: Through segregated deaf schools that isolated Black deaf communities
